title: GlassWire 2.1.167 vulnerability - MSVR 56639

profile.name: GlassWire
profile.about: GlassWire helps protect your computer and privacy by monitoring your network activity.

vulnerability_information:
Arbitrary code execution vulnerability within the firewall software, GlassWire version 2.1.167

## Impact

After the program is installed, on first execution, it will attempt to load Wtsapi32.dll.dll from the user's PATH (without doing any checks to see if the file is signed). Attached is a demo leveraging this vulnerability to spawn notepad.exe as well as screenshots showing the software searching the user’s PATH.

activities.message: Using a video to demonstrate a potential issue should only be necessary for rare situations and should always be accompanied by a text description of the issue as well. Please update this report with step-by-step instructions to reproduce the core components of the issue. That will help the team be able to more easily reproduce the same behavior. Thank you!

Please find my repro steps below. NOTE: these steps were performed using the updated version of GlassWire – 2.3.323. The issue of the software checking the user’s PATH for the .dll seems to be resolved; however, I can still achieve arbitrary code execution by specifying an installation directory with lower permission applied (i.e somewhere in the user profile).

1.	Installed ProcessMonitor from Sysinternals (Process Monitor - Windows Sysinternals | Microsoft Docs).
2.	In the ‘Filter’ tab within Process Monitor, created the following filters and pressed ‘Add’ to add each one
a.	ProcessName is GlassWire.exe then Include
b.	Operation is CreateFile then Include
c.	Path contains Wtsapi32.dll.dll then Include
3.	In the list of icons shown in the picture   unchecked the circled ones.
4.	Installed GlassWire v2.3.323.
5.	When it prompts for installation directory, I chose a directory on my Desktop.
6.	At the end of installation, made sure ‘Run GlassWire 2.3’ is checked.
7.	Before pressing ‘Finish’, placed a custom, unisgned .dll into the installation directory and named it Wtsapi32.dll.dll. (the custom .dll spawns notepad.exe)
8.	Pressed ‘Finish’ to run GlassWire and it spawned a notepad.exe window.
Thank you for your report.  I need to know the exact Windows version you used for this report.
Windows 10 Pro, version 10.0.19041 Build 19041.
Thanks, we will investigate.
Okay, thank you.
We continue to investigate, thank you for your report.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/64gmhomwwhpmn5l/glasswire-setup-2.3.328-full.exe?dl=0

Please try the installer above and let me know if the issue is solved.  Please note GlassWire does not run as admin, so we don't feel your reporting the severity of this as "high" is appropriate.
Did the new version solve the issue?  Please confirm.

I will respond when the researcher has tried the proposed fix. 

Kind regards,

James 
MSVR
Hello James, if you are not the researcher then who are you and how are you related to this report?  Just curious.  Thanks.
I work as the Security Project Manager - SPM for cases like this. I will get a response from the researcher as soon as possible.
May I ask what company/organization you represent?  Do you represent HackerOne, or another organization?

We appreciate your report, however we have just reviewed the HackerOne code of conduct https://www.hackerone.com/policies/code-of-conduct that states "sharing account access and submitting the work of other Hackers" is not allowed.  Please explain what's going on here with multiple people using this account and the hacker themselves not responding to us after we put out a fix.  We don't understand what's going on here.
I used the HackerOne vulnerability tool and this vulnerability was changed to medium by HackerOne.

Any update on what's going on with several people using this account?  We don't understand why several people are involved in this process and nobody is answering after we made a custom version for the reporter.  Thank you for your report and sorry if we are misunderstanding something? 

It has almost been a week since we gave you the fix to check.

I will update you when we know if the update was successful.

Kind regards,

James
Microsoft Vulnerability Research
Thank you for your explanation. We look forward to receiving your feedback on the fix.

Thanks again for your detailed report.  We believe we fixed the issue and we'd like to release an update.  Could you confirm the fix we submitted solves the problem if your team member is currently available?
I did not mean to change the status to "Triaged".
Hello, I can confirm that the fix worked as per the researcher. Will there be a CVE created?

I will investigate how to make a report a CVE when it goes public, please wait while I investigate.  Please let your researcher know we are grateful for their report.  Thanks!

Also, normally we pay a bounty.  If we did so, would this go to the researcher or who?
The fix is now live.  Thank you for your report!
Do you have a CVE or security advisory issued?

We do not have a CVE or security advisory issued.  We are currently investigating best practices on CVE/Security Advisories due to your request.  If you could provide additional guidance it would be most appreciated.  Normally we use HackerOne to automatically disclose the reports with its default settings https://hackerone.com/glasswire/hacktivity?type=team.
Thank you for reporting this issue so we could solve it, then release the fix to the public.
We continue to investigate how to release the CVE using HackerOne.
I have requested the CVE via HackerOne as shown with their help system.
Ok, thank you! Will await the CVE number.
Following up to see if you have published a CVE for this vulnerability?

We now have instructions from HackerOne on the CVE, but we'd like to wait until we alert all our users to upgrade.  We are waiting for our latest release to do the upgrade alert.  I apologize for the delay.  Thanks for your patience, and thanks again for your report.

Meanwhile the fix was released awhile back on August 3.
Ok, thank you for the response. Can you share the CVE number?
We have not reserved a CVE ID yet, but we have the instructions from HackerOne when we're ready.

I am still working on the CVE, just making sure it's done correctly since this is our first one.  I apologize for the delay.

If you could show an example recent CVE that was done through HackerOne related to a report you made it might help me.

https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln-metrics/cvss/v3-calculator

Maybe this will help. You can assess the CVSS score for the vulnerability with this tool. You will need to create a CVE for the respective software vulnerability.

You can certainly search for something similar with this tool. https://cve.mitre.org/cve/search_cve_list.html

Otherwise, can Hackerone help you?

We do want to close out our case and need a security advisory issued or CVE created and published.
It is submitted:  We have assigned your CVE request for GlassWire report #1193641 the CVE ID CVE-2021-22961. We will submit these updates to MITRE for approval.  Thank you.
It appears it must be disclosed before the CVE is live, so you should approve the disclosure.
Ok, approved.
I looked and it appears that the CVE was already released on 10/18/2021. One issue is that you did not mention the Microsoft researcher responsible for the find by name?

I apologize.  I believe this HackerOne thread is referenced in the CVE if you'd like to give the name of the researcher here?  I used the HackerOne system to release the CVE and I don't recall there being a place to put any specific names, but perhaps I missed it somehow.
Katie Lewis Microsoft

summaries.content: On May 12th Katie Lewis at Microsoft found GlassWire 2.1.167 would attempt to load Wtsapi32.dll.dll from the user's PATH (without doing any checks to see if the file is signed).  GlassWire's team sent a fix that Katie Lewis confirmed solved the issue, then released an update with the fix.
